title: How to Replace the Chain on a Chainsaw

steps.headline: Put on safety gloves.
steps.description: You’ll be handling a chain, a chainsaw blade, and a screwdriver, so wear thick safety gloves to minimize your risk of injury. Also, consult the safety manual that came with your chainsaw for any other recommended safety equipment to wear or safety tips to follow. While you won’t need to turn your chainsaw on while you replace the chain, you may want to test it afterward. Make sure to put on goggles, hearing protection, and other safety equipment when you operate the chainsaw.

steps.headline: Unlock the chainsaw brake and then test it to make sure it's disengaged.
steps.description: To unlock the brake, pull the front handle backward. Then, grip the chain between your thumb and forefingers and move it forward parallel to the guide bar. If it moves, the brake has been disengaged. If you don’t disengage the brake first, it will be extremely difficult to replace the side plate once you’ve removed it.Warning: Make sure your chainsaw is off and unplugged before working on it so you don't injure yourself.

steps.headline: Loosen the tensioning screw with a screwdriver.
steps.description: This screw can be found on the side of the chainsaw guide bar where it meets the handle. Insert your flathead screwdriver into the head and turn it counter-clockwise to loosen. Make sure not to remove the tensioning screw fully.

steps.headline: Use a socket wrench to remove the side panel.
steps.description: Unscrew the two nuts that should be affixing a panel to the left side of your chainsaw. Place the drive socket around one of the nuts and twist in a counter-clockwise motion until the nut comes loose. Place the nut on a workbench or table, and repeat with the second nut. Take the panel off and place it on the table. You should clean out any sawdust or other debris that is in the side panel.

steps.headline: Pull the guide bar off the sprocket and away from the handle.
steps.description: The sprocket is the wheel with cogs on it that the chain is wrapped around. After you pull the guide bar off of it, grip the guide bar between your thumb and forefinger, and pull it away from the handle until you see the chain has become slack. Detaching the bar from the rest of the chainsaw is the easiest way to replace a chain, although you can pull the chain off by pulling the nose forward on some models. Use this opportunity to determine if you should sharpen or polish the blade as well.

steps.headline: Slide the loose chain off the guide bar.
steps.description: Grip the chain itself between a thumb and forefinger, and pull the drive links, which keep the chain affixed to the guide bar, up and away from the bar. Pull the end close to the handle away from the clutch drum (the round, metal cap that the sprocket is attached to), then set the old chain aside on your table or workbench. If your chain is extremely gnarled or mangled, be extra careful, even with gloves on.

steps.headline: Slide the new chain around the clutch drum and blade.
steps.description: Make sure your chain’s drive links, not its cutting teeth, are facing forward and are gripping the guide bar. Otherwise, you won’t be able to cut anything. Use your fingers to wrap your chain around the nose and body of the guide bar, as well as the clutch drum. When you’ve done this, slide the guide bar back on the sprocket.Tip: Chainsaw chains come with 3 specifications: pitch, gauge, and total drive links. When you're shopping for a new chain, you'll need to get one that matches the specifications for your chainsaw. If you're not sure what your chainsaw's specifications are, you can find them on the original packaging or look them up online.

steps.headline: Replace the side plate.
steps.description: Place the side plate in its prior position, then replace a nut in its socket. Place the socket wrench around the head of the nut and turn clockwise once or twice to tighten, leaving the side plate loose. Then repeat with the second nut. Don’t fully tighten the nuts as you want to adjust the chain to have just the right amount of tension.

steps.headline: Tighten the tensioning screw with your screwdriver.
steps.description: Remove the slack from the chain by inserting the head of your flathead screwdriver into the tensioning screw and turning clockwise. The chain should be tight enough that if you pull it up from the guide bar, you can just barely pull it away from the guide bar. Pull the chain alongside the guide bar to make sure that it can move freely. If it is hard to move, you’ve tightened the tension screw too much and should loosen it.

steps.headline: Use the socket wrench to tighten the nuts on the side plate.
steps.description: Now that the chainsaw has the right amount of tension, place the head of the socket wrench on each nut and tighten by turning in a clockwise motion.

steps.headline: Test your chainsaw once you're finished putting on the new chain.
steps.description: Once you fire up your chainsaw, rev the engine and let it run for a few seconds. Then, turn the chainsaw off, and check the chain to make sure it's lubricated. If it's not, there might be an issue with the lubrication system. Additionally, try cutting something with the chainsaw. If you have to force the chainsaw through the object, it's a sign that's something is wrong. Always wear personal protective equipment while you're operating a chainsaw.
